availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Organized at Camp Clay, Ohio, in June 1861 under Colonel James V. Guthrie (U.S.A). Mustered into United States service on June 4, 1861. On July 10, 1861, it was ordered to the Kanawha Valley, West Virginia. Attached to the Kanawha Brigade while in West Virginia from October 1861 to January 1862. Involved in skirmish at Gauley Bridge on October 23, 1861. Sent to Charleston, West Virginia on December 4, 1861 where it remained until January 5, 1862. Colonel David E. Enyart (U.S.A.) commissioned to command unit in December 1861 following the resignation of Colonel Guthrie. Colonel Enyart commanded regiment throughout its whole enlistment. January 5, 1862 ordered to the Department of the Cumberland and took an active role in the advance to Nashville, Tennessee. Involved in the Battle of Shiloh April 6 and 7, 1862. Then advanced on Corinth, Mississippi where it contributed to the Siege of Corinth between April 29 and May 30, 1862. During the summer of 1862, the unit was involved in Major General Don Carlos Buell’s (U.S.A.) campaign in Northern Alabama and Middle Tennessee. Following that between August 21 and September 25, 1862, the First Kentucky marched to Louisville, Kentucky in pursuit of General Braxton Bragg (C.S.A). Pursuit of Bragg led them to Loudon, Kentucky between October 1 and 22, 1862. Fought in the Battle of Perryville on October 8, 1862, and then destroyed the saltworks at Goose Creek, Kentucky on October 23, 1862. Marched to Nashville, Tennessee between October 24 and November 9, 1862. Remained on duty there until December 26, 1862. Involved in the Battle of Stone’s River December 30 and 31, 1862 and January 1 to 3, 1863. Its next significant activity was during the Tullahoma Campaign between June 24 and July 7, 1863, and then it was involved in the Chickamauga Campaign between August 16 to September 22, 1863. Following involvement in the Siege of Chattanooga between September 24 and October 27, 1863, the First Kentucky was on duty in Bridgeport, Alabama until January 26, 1864. One of its last operations was during Brigadier General John H. Morgan’s (C.S.A) invasion of Kentucky between May and June 1864. The First Kentucky mustered out of service on June 18, 1864.

ab.bibl: Report of the Adjutant General of the State of Kentucky, vol. 1, 1861-1866 (Frankfort: Kentucky Yeoman Office, 1866), 557. Frederick H. Dyer, A Compendium of the War of the Rebellion, Volume 1 (Des Moines: The Dyer Publishing Company, 1908), 1197-1198.
